newsitem.title: INDIA: Political fears drag Bombay shares down at close.
newsitem.headline: Political fears drag Bombay shares down at close.

text.p: Share prices fell broadly on Thursday at the Bombay and National bourses in jittery trade caused by fresh worries of political uncertainty, brokers said.

They said sellers outnumbered buyers in sluggish trade after a court rejected an anticipatory bail request by former prime minister P.V. Narasimha Rao against possible arrest in a criminal conspiracy case.

"There's extreme pessimism," said one trader. "Collectively, bearish." The 30-share Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) index ended 38.42 points, or 1.15 percent, lower at a provisional 3,305.50 off the day's low of 3,293.71.
The 50-stock National Stock Exchange (NSE) index dropped 11.99 points, or 1.23 percent, to a provisional 959.01.
The 500-share CRISIL index shed 7.42 points to a provisional 642.22.
The minority coalition government of Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda depends on the support of Rao's Congress party.
On Saturday, Rao stepped down as the president of the Congress after a judge ordered him to personally appear in court as a co-accused in the case.
Two other people accused in the case are in jail pending trial.
Traders said most funds were net sellers during the day. Only the state-owned insurance firms were net buyers.
Bank share SBI fell 5.0 rupees to 259.25 on the BSE. It lost 4.95 to 259.85 at the NSE.
Analysts said a further fall in prices could mar SBI's $400 million global depositary receipt issue which was expected to be priced at a premium to the underlying stock.
IPCL fell 7.0 to 115 after its chief said he expects a net profit of 2.2 billion rupees in the first six months to September 30, against 3.05 billion in the year-ago period.
